summary: Charles A. Briggs was involved in handling Freedom of Information and Privacy Acts requests. In 1977, he expressed appreciation for the support he received from the Privacy and Information Action Group (PIAG) and others as he transitioned out of the DDO Information Review Officer role. Later, he appears to have been involved in the CIA's experience with the JFK Records Review, specifically regarding the release of JFK assassination records. The documents suggest he was involved in the process of declassification and release of information related to the JFK assassination, including addressing the handling of cryptonyms, pseudonyms, file numbers, and employee names, and the extent of redactions.
significance: Charles A. Briggs' significance in the JFK context lies in his involvement in the declassification and release of JFK assassination records. He was part of the CIA's process of reviewing and releasing information, dealing with sensitive data like cryptonyms and employee names, and negotiating redactions with the ARRB.
